lead_paragraph: A study shows the potential benefits, but if the past is any guide, what’s effective will nonetheless be politically unpalatable.

byline.contributor: Aaron E. Carroll is a professor of pediatrics at Indiana University School of Medicine who blogs on health research and policy at The Incidental Economist and makes videos at Healthcare Triage. Follow him on Twitter at @aaronecarroll.

headline.print_headline: Limiting Food Stamp Choices  May Help Fight Obesity
headline.main: How Restricting Food Stamp Choices Can Fight Obesity

snippet: A study shows the potential benefits, but if the past is any guide, what’s effective will nonetheless be politically unpalatable....
abstract: The Upshot; food insecurity is linked to obesity, as poor people find it harder to eat healthfully; recent study points up benefits of changing behavioral economics of food, but politics involved are problematical; more than 44 million Americans are on food stamps, with average aid of $255 monthly.
